did.abstract: Consortium of universities created to study tropical environments focusing on Central America and field activities in tropical habitats. The University of Michigan became a founding member of OTS in April 1963. Administrative records chiefly concerning University of Michigan involvement in the Organization for Tropical Studies and related programs. Records include initial planning documents, committee files, meeting minutes, proposals, reports, topical files and curriculum material. Includes correspondence of Norman Hartweg and Stephen Spurr; also records collected by Warren H. Wagner.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Organization for Tropical Studies records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Organization for Tropical Studies (OTS) was created as a consortium of universities to operate a graduate program in the area of tropical research. The University of Michigan became a founding member of OTS in April 1963.

The organization was officially founded in 1962. The origins of OTS come from a committee at the University of Michigan interested in a proposed center for biological study which began in 1956. In 1958 there were several visits to Mexico as a potential location for the project, but this was later abandoned at the suggestion of Mexican officials. In the fall of 1962 a new committee was formed under professors Norman Hartweg and Stephen Spurr with the idea of bringing together a consortium of universities. Hartweg and Spurr were particularly instrumental in writing the original articles of agreement that led to incorporation in the State of Florida. The by-laws and charter were adopted at another conference in Coral Gables, Florida in February 1963 where Hartweg was elected as the first president of OTS, while Thomas Hubbell also of the University of Michigan faculty served as a member of the Board of Directors.

In March 1963, before becoming a member of OTS, the Michigan Committee on Tropical Studies (MCOTS) was formed. This committee was created to support and promote OTS at the University of Michigan. It was later disbanded.

The purpose of OTS is to further the understanding of the tropics through formal graduate courses and individual research projects in tropical areas. OTS typically has involved about 150 graduate students and 50 faculty members from nearly as many institutions, each year. Funds are obtained through grants from the National Science Foundation as well as other organizations. Emphasis is placed on field instruction, which can be carried on only in tropical environments. Courses are offered in various areas of biology, geography, forestry, earth sciences, biometeorology, and marine sciences. The principle area of concentration has been in Central America, particularly Costa Rica, with a Central American Office located at the University of Costa Rica, and with special agreements for study areas in Guatemala near Escuintla and on the Colombian island of San Andres in the Caribbean. Course offerings emphasize field activities in all of the major tropical habitats where classes meet continuously for periods of one to two weeks. Field locations are selected to provide a spectrum of tropical environments including dry lowlands, wet lowlands, highlands and marine areas. Lodging and field laboratory facilities are arranged through rental of commercial and private establishments, and by a network of permanent field stations.

OTS does not employ a permanent teaching staff. Courses are taught by eminent scientists drawn from the faculties and staffs of universities and scientific organizations throughout the world. A balance of scientific specialities appropriate to each course is provided by two or more faculty members and supporting visiting scientists and local lecturers who are involved for periods which vary from one or two days to several weeks.

Membership to OTS is by institution only. In 1995 there were approximately 50 to 60 member institutions paying an approximate $10,000 annual membership fee, which supports the North American executive offices now located at Duke University.

scopecontent.p: The records from the Organization for Tropical Studies (OTS) measure 10 linear feet, spanning the years from 1948 to 1986. It is comprised of 13 series: Committee Records; Correspondence; Education Program; Establishment Files; Financial Records; Meeting Files; Membership Records; Projects, Proposals, and Reports; Topical Files, Writings, Files from the office of Warren H. Wagner, and Organizing Committee. There is a related collection of OTS material at Duke University as well as related material located as part of the Stephen H. Spurr papers.

The Committee Records (.7 linear feet; 1959-1984) series consists of minutes and correspondences of various committees formed within OTS. The Michigan Committee on Tropical Studies (MCOTS) is included in this series, but the Executive Committee is not because it is part of the Meeting Files series. There are ad hoc and standing committees included. This series is organized alphabetically by the title of the committee.

did.unittitle: National Park Services of Costa Rica 1971-1972

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence (1 linear foot; 1963-1986) series gives the best feeling for the atmosphere of OTS. It includes the correspondence of three OTS presidents, two of which were from the University of Michigan, Thomas Hubbell and Stephen Preston. It is organized chronologically with the exception of selected folders which are ordered alphabetically by correspondent or institution.

The Education Program series (.7 linear feet; 1964-1978) includes information about the courses offered and related educational concerns. This series contains course announcements, class schedules, correspondence regarding courses offered, course evaluations, and coordinating educational programs with member universities. This series is organized alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Undergraduate Program and Associated Colleges of the Midwest 1973-1974

scopecontent.p: Establishment Files (.3 linear feet and 4 bound volume; 1956-1970) is a series that contains the correspondence, memos, statements, and the by-laws and charter of the beginning of OTS. The original material is in 4 bound volumes, and additional material is in folders. The bound material is organized chronologically, and the folders are alphabetically arranged.

did.unittitle: Committee on a Proposed Center for Tropical Studies (CENTROP) 1959-1965
University of Michigan Proposal for CENTROP 1956-1959

scopecontent.p: The Financial Records (.5 linear feet; 1958-1977) series is composed of general financial operations, OTS debt, National Science Foundation grants, and member support material. It is organized alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Task Force on the Organization and Financial Management of OTS 1976

scopecontent.p: The Meetings Files (1.5 linear feet; 1963-1981) series is largely made up of minutes, memos, and correspondences from meetings of the Board of Directors and the Executive Committee. The Board of Directors met annually and the Executive Committee met twice a year. This series is organized alphabetically and chronologically.

The Membership Records (.3 linear feet; 1966-1977) series is composed of lists of members. It includes member institutions, institution representation on the Board of Directors and Executive Committee. It is organized alphabetically.

The Projects, Proposals, and Reports (.4 linear feet; 1957-1977) series is made up of three files: Projects, Proposals, and Reports. The Projects subseries contains information on projects which the organization was working on or planning. The Proposals file includes suggestions for future projects for OTS. The Reports series includes evaluation of OTS by individuals and institutions. This series and the files are organized alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Marine Resources in North West Costa Rica 1977
Advances in Tropical Wood Science undated

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files (1.3 linear feet; 1948-1974) series is an alphabetical listing of OTS general organizational files. These records document decisions, debates, and processes of OTS. They contain information on conferences, workshops, field stations, and annual reports.

did.unittitle: Ecology of Development in Central America and Panama 1974
Costa Rican National Council of Science and Technology (CONICIT) 1981
Faculty Statements of Interest in OTS (University of Michigan) undated
Workshop on Development and the Environment 1970-1971

scopecontent.p: The Writings (.3 linear feet; 1955-1977) series includes drafts of publicity brochures, correspondence on a monograph series, and newsletters. Also included are some writings by various OTS faculty.

did.unittitle: Files from the office of Warren H. Wagner 1949-1972

scopecontent.p: Files from the office of Warren H. Wagner (1.0 linear feet, 1949-1972) contain correspondence, course materials, materials from the National Science Foundation, a proposal for the establishment of a center for teaching and research in the isthmus of Tehuantepec (preliminary draft and supporting letters), OTS Executive Committee Meeting materials, and Annual Report of OTS (1969).

did.unittitle: Letters to William Steere regarding his proposal for a tropical biological station 1949
Request to National Science Foundation: "A continuing program of graduate education in tropical studies" 1972
Proposal for the establishment of a center for teaching and research in the isthmus of Tehuantepec (preliminary draft and supporting letters) 1956-1956
Basic References for OTS Executive Committee Meeting

scopecontent.p: The Organizing Committee (1 linear foot, 1949-1963) series includes early drafts of the constitution and by-laws, correspondence, planning committee notes, Tropical Center development materials; reports (1958-1963; 4 folders), occasional papers, research papers, official lists of tropical plants and animals; proposal for a Coordinated Research Program in Mexico, Tehuantepec Report (revised), surveys, materials from survey-trips to Mexico, maps, physical plant estimated costs, National Referral Center for Science and Technology, newsletters, brochures, and other (affiliated) institutions. The materials are primarily in English, though is a significant quantity of Spanish language materials. Mexico was the initial site for the proposed field station. Costa Rica, in the end, was the home of the field station. This series is useful for background information for the Organization for Tropical Studies. Marginalia notes on correspondence, meeting notes, and planning documents lend insight into the organizing process. Personal correspondence as well as official committee documents reveal the successes and frustrations of organizing an international, tropical field station.

did.unittitle: Official Lists of Tropical Plants and Animals 1959-1962
Coordinated Program for Research in Mexico 1948-1949
Surveys for Interest in Tehuantepec, Mexico Project 1957
Estimates of Cost for Physical Plant 1959
National Referral Center for Science and Technology 1962-1963
